NOTEBOOK OF TED HAGOS

On Java 8

You can get Java 8 by way of Oracle Early Access. This is a mainstream, run of the mill installer though. That means you install this on a machine, it takes over the Java environment for that machine. Don't do that! Not to your workhorse and go-to machine. Do it a VM, it is safer and prudent that way.

On a Debian VM or Debian-ish machines, it can be pulled from the repos


sudo add-apt-repository ppa:webupd8team/java
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install oracle-java8-installer

The Windows installation should be easy to figure out, there is no need to write it here.

If you cannot go the VM route you can still try out Java 8. There is a downloadable version of Java 8 Development Kit at java8.jdk.net/downloadthat does not require installation. You may need to figure out how to use side-by-side with your other installation of the JDK though. For my Mac setup, this is what I did

  1. Download the installer from java8.jdk.net/download or java8.jdk.net/lambda, the second one is larger and has lambda support
  2. Extract the contents and tuck it away somewhere
  3. Create softlinks to the java8 executables, might be a good idea not to override your usual java and javac. I named mine java8 and javac8

sudo ln -s /somewhere/jdk8/bin/java /usr/bin/java8
sudo ln -s /somewhere/jdk8/bin/javac /usr/bin/javac8

I hope some people in the community will already invest sometime on something like rvm for Java, so I won't have to do this with Java 9

file: #java8 #jdk8 #early_access
